summary: HSV-1 is an enveloped, linear double-stranded DNA virus. diseases caused by herpes simplex include cold sores, keratoconjunctivitis, genital herpes and encephalitis. treatments currently directed against HSV infections are nucleoside analogs. anthraquinones derivatives like aloe-emodin, rhein, emodin, and chrysophanol demonstrated antiviral effects. but as with most Chinese herbal medicines, the application of rhubarb is limited due to its poor bioavailability and hydrophobicity. nanoparticles might resolve the biopharmaceutical problems related to improving the uptake of poorly soluble drugs, reducing toxicity and increasing the drug bioavailability the in vivo efficacies of R. tanguticum nanoparticles were investigated with a mouse model of HSV-1 encephalitis. the positive results offer a novel promising way for the usage of Chinese herbal medicine to control the HSV-1 infection. the mobile phase composed of A) methanol and B) 0.1% (v/v) phosphoric acid water solution was delivered at a rate of 1 ml/min. the reference marker compounds of aloe-emodin, rhein, emodin, chrysophanol and physcion for high-performance liquid chromatography were purchased from the Shanghai Standard Technology Co., Ltd. HEp-2 cells in 96-well plates were incubated with various concentrations of R. tanguticum nanoparticles at 37°C in an atmosphere of 5% CO2. the virus was propagated in HEp-2 cells and stored at 80°C for further studies. the plaques developed after 72 h of incubation were fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde for 10 min. the plaques were counted and the percentages of inhibition were calculated. the effective concentration of test compound that reduced plaques number by 50% (EC50) was calculated. HEp-2 cell monolayers were pre-chilled at 4°C for 1 h. the medium was replaced with different concentrations of cold R. tanguticum nanoparticles and was incubated for 2 h at 4°C. the cells were washed twice with cold PBS and were covered with methylcellulose to allow viral adsorption. the immediate early gene 4 (encoding ICP4), early gene U L 29 (encoding ICP8) and late gene U S 6 (encoding glycoprotein gD) were determined by using a Bio-Rad CFX96 instrument. the transcription levels of total RNA in each sample were standardized against the GAPDH gene. cells were infected with HSV-1 at an MOI of 0.01. soluble fraction was clarified by centrifugation at 12,000 g for 5 min at 4°C. membranes were blocked with 5% BSA for 2 h, rinsed and then incubated. mice were anesthetized intraperitoneally by ketamine (100 mg/kg) and injected intracerebrally with 20 l serial dilutions of HSV-1(HSV-1 F strain) no death and obvious weight loss were seen when R. tanguticum nanoparticles were at dosages below 2,500 mg/kg/day. the mice were randomly assigned to 5 groups and inoculated intracerebrally with 20 l of DMEM (Gibco, Grand Island, NY) containing either no virus (vehicle only) or 5LD50 of HSV-1(HSV-1 F strain. after 5 h, the inoculated mice received either dissolved in Saline (0.9%) before administration to mice with the indicated dose at 625 mg/kg/day or 312.5 mg/kg/day. assays, brains of four mice per group were collected on day 5 post infection. total RNA was extracted from brain tissues with TRIzol reagent. expression of two viral genes was determined using RT-qPCR. R. tanguticum nanoparticles were characterized by a transmission electron microscope. a drop of R. tanguticum nanoparticles suspension was placed on a carbon coated-copper grid and evaporated to form a monolayer at room temperature. the elemental analysis was carried out with an accelerating voltage of 80 kV. the zeta potential (ZP) of R. tanguticum nanoparticles was measured with the same instrument. the samples were suspended in distilled water and were analyzed in triplicate at a temperature of 25°C. the optical density at 570 nm was then determined by a conventional microplate reader (MultiskanTM GO; Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA). the CC50 was calculated using a regression analysis. the virus inocula were added to HEp-2 cell monolayers. after adsorption for 2 h, the viral inoculum were discarded. the cells were washed once with PBS, and then overlaid with overlay media. HEp-2 cells were infected with HSV-1 at an MOI of 0.01. the cells were harvested at each time point (6, 12, 18, and 24 h) for western blot analysis of ICP4 and ICP8. survival time, lethality and viral titers in the brains were recorded to determine the antiviral efficiency of R. tanguticum nanoparticles. survival rates were 30.0% and 60.0%, which are higher than the viral control group (20.0%) on the 14th day post-infection. ing mice (n = 10 mice/group) infected with 5 LD50 of HSV-1 were orally administered with 625 mg/kg/day and 312.5 mg/kg/day. a 0.9% saline was used in viral control and normal control group. survival rates were collected daily for 14 day. treatment with R. tanguticum nanoparticles at 312.5 mg/kg/day is similar to those in virus group. post-treatment with R. tanguticum nanoparticles can alleviate severity of brain damage in the virus-infected mice. the expression of the ICP4 protein of the brain tissue was detected by Western blot analysis. the mRNA levels of the ICP4 and ICP8 were determined by real-time quantitative PCR analysis. the morphology and size of R. tanguticum nanoparticles were characterized by using TEM and DLS techniques. the mean particle size of R. tanguticum nanoparticles calculated by TEM was around 123.2 nm. hep-2 cells were treated with serial dilutions of R. tanguticum nanoparticles at 37°C for 72 h. the 50% cytotoxic concentration (CC50) of R. tanguticum nanoparticles on HEp-2 cells was 415.3 g/ml.
